text: Dogs catching Frisbees in the park... Some fat old geezer playing chess... Autumn leaves.
I was thinking maybe the Bugle could show another side of New York for a change—-

Parker, if I believed for one second those pictures were an accurate reflection of this town, I'd hang myself from the top of the Chrysler Building. I don't pay you to be a sensitive artist! I pay you because for some reason that psycho Spider-Man will pose for you.
Well, it's like I told you, Mr. Jameson. Spider-Man won't let me take any more pictures of him. He says you only use them to slander him. You've turned the whole city against him.

A fact I'm very proud of! Having that lunatic around has weakened the moral fiber of New York! The police are demoralized! The citizens lazy! Now get your pretty little "portfolio" out of my face before I go into a diabetic coma!

Mr. Jameson, please. You can't fire me. Even working two jobs I can barely make tuition, and Aunt May's social security doesn't amount to... JJJ mimes tying a noose around his neck, throws his head back, thrusts his tongue from his mouth. Peter folds.

What if--all right, what if I did have a shot of Spider-Man? Peter reaches into his knapsack and takes out a manila folder. Slides out a fantastic shot of Spider-Man saving nun from an oncoming meat truck. JJJ eyes it hungrily.
It stinks. I'll give you three hundred. He reaches for it. Peter snatches it back.
No. There's no way I can sell you this shot... until you agree to run more balanced coverage of Spider- Man.
I take my journalistic responsibility to present balanced coverage very seriously Parker, you know that. Fine. I'll give you four. I'll nominate him for a goddamn medal, Parker. You have my word.
Five.
That's outrageous. (beat) Done. Peter lets go of the photo, then sits a moment. Knowing h has just made big mistake.
All right, you've wasted enough of my precious time, Parker. Get lost.

Time. Right. Peter snaps out of it, looks at his watch: oh, shit. He l to his feet, grabs his knapsack, and runs out. EXT. MINEO'S PIZZA — DAY Peter rides up on an elderly Kawasaki: RUMBLING, COUGHING SPUTTERING. Not a well machine. On the back, a hotbox wit the Mineo's logo. Peter leaps off and runs into the pizze A PAGER beeps. INT. MINEO'S — DAY Peter hurtles into the shop, out of breath, frantic. Yank the pager from his pocket.
Sorry! Mr. Aziz, I'm sorry. MR. AZIZ hangs up the phone. The BEEPING stops. Life has disappointed Mr. Aziz; Peter's only a side-manifestation.

Twenty-one minutes ago, in comes an order from the high-quality law firm of Foehn, Harmattan & Buran for seventeen extra large deep-dish pizzas. In eight minutes, I am defaulting on the Mineo's twenty- nine minute guarantee. Indeed numerous banners and signs proclaim the sacred number. MR. AZIZ (cont'd) Then not only will I be receiving no money for these pizzas, I will lose the customer forever to Pizza Yurt. And they are killing me already.
Why didn't you send Salim?
Salim was deported yesterday. I have no hope but you. You must make it in time. He starts thrusting pizzas at Peter, stacking them in Pet arms until we can't see his face anymore.

You are a nice young man, Peter, but you are not dependable. This is the last chance I can give you. You must cross forty-two blocks in seven and one half minutes. Or your ass is to be fired. Peter checks the big Mineo's clock. It's 5:44.
Peter runs to his bike, dumps the pizzas into the hotbox. Climbs on, kicks it. Nothing. Kicks it again. Nothing.

I don't believe this! Mr. Aziz watches, contemplating suicide. Peter kicks it o more and it starts. He goes slobbering off. EXT. NEW YORK STREET — DAY Peter halted. Looks at his watch. 5:47. A van has collided with a Town Car. The DRIVERS are on th street, shouting and threatening each other. The PASSENGE gets out, too. The three men come to blows. Peter pops up onto the sidewalk. Mistake. An old lady ina wheelchair comes out of nowhere. Peter hits the brakes. Swerves. The bike stalls. He kicks wildly at the starter: dead. And it's 5:48. Peter leaps off the bike. With a mighty heave he wrenches hotbox right off the back of the motorcycle, snapping bol twisting metal. Then he ducks into an alley. EXT. LOWER MANHATTAN - NEW YORK STREET — AERIAL SHOT Spider-Man swings toward the Woolworth Building. One-hand since the hotbox is tucked under his left arm. At the end each arc he freefalls until he shoots the next strand of Below, two boys chase each other and a basketball into th street. A car is coming right at them. Spider-Man's spider sense tingles. He looks down; sees th trajectories of car, ball and boys, pure vectors of physi plotted against the air: collision. Spider-Man heaves the hotbox away. It arcs heavenward. Wi his hand now free, he shoots a strand of web. A lasso of web encircles the boys and yanks the boys towa the opposite side of the street.  Sets them on their feet. The car squeals past, horn BLARING. The boys, dazed. The basketball shoots in, a web-slung ch pass. One of them catches it. They look up at the sky. Spider-Man catches up to the hotbox as it hurtles earthwa past him. Snags it with a web and drags it back up. The Woolworth Building looms. Spider-Man snags its pinnacle a arcs around it, circling in.
Peter rushes in with the stack of pizzas. Out of breath, of wild looking. A big, silly grin on his face.
Pizza time! He sets the pizzas on the desk. The receptionist stares a him, then at the pizzas: disgust. Peter looks--there's a of webbing on the top box. Sheepish he scrapes it off.
Sorry. INT. MINEO'S PIZZA — EVENING Peter struts in, grinning.
Mr. Aziz! I'm back! I-- Mr. Aziz whirls on him.
You are fired, that is what you are. The pizzas arrived three minutes late! Peter, the twenty- nine minute guarantee is a promise. I know a promise means nothing to you, but to me it is serious.
It's serious to me, too, Mr. Aziz. Honestly. Please, I need this job, please give me another chance. Mr. Aziz shakes his head. Peter gives up.

Peter's tired old Kawasaki pulls up in front of the build backfiring. He climbs off it.  Trudges into the lobby. SPIDER SENSE. Peter's surging HEARTBEAT. A shadow looms. Peter jumps back, then lashes out and grabs hold of his attacker. Ducks, twists, flips a very large man over his shoulder. The guy SLAMS against the lobby floor. It's a b SECURITY GOON. Peter has flattened the guy.
Christ, I think you broke my tailbone!
Oh, man, I'm sorry, I--
I was only going ask for your ID!
My ID? Since when--?
Peter takes out his key. But instead of a keyhole there's card-reader. He's puzzled. The door flies open.
What the hell you did to my security guy?

He surprised me! I grabbed him and he... he must have lost his footing. (how lame!) I think they just waxed the lobby. (changing the subject) What's with the muscleman, Harry? Did somebody threaten you?
You're kidding, right? Pete, I'm lucky Spider-Man hasn't killed me already! He knows I'll spend every last dime I have to take him down.

Harry. I'm worried about you. You've really gotten kind of... He takes a slender hybrid PDA/remote from his pocket. Tap some buttons. Titanium bars slide across the windows. Steel shutters c down. Laser trip-beams spin a glowing web across the livi room. Another beam lances from the ceiling and performs a retinal scan of Peter. He flinches.
...paranoid. Harry holds up the screen of his super-Palm. It reads ID CONFIRMED: PARKER, PETER.
I guess you're who you seem to be.
Please just tell me you didn't put a camera in the bathroom. Harry taps, and all the barriers retract; the beams die. gets right in Peter's face. Trying to be funny but with w intensity.
You could save me a buttload of money and trouble if you would just tell me how you always manage to find the guy. .»PETER'S FACE The impossibility of the situation; the pain.
I would if I could. I swear to you. Harry stares at him, searching his face. Something there he doesn't quite believe. Peter struggles to meet Harry's searching gaze. Falters. Fails.
That's fine. No, I'm serious. You don't need me, I don't need you. We're not even really friends, are we? Takes two tickets from his pocket, tosses them on the tab
Hear are those tickets you wanted. That Octavius guy at Columbia. Have fun.
Octavius! Otto Octavius is the god of arachnid biomimetics. Harry, I know you're mad at me, but come on! You can't miss that! Peter is perfectly serious. Harry can't help smiling.
Lord have mercy on my soul.
You promised you'd introduce me to him! The rage flares up again in Harry.
And you promised to help me get Spider Man! (subsides ) All right, fine. I keep my promises.
Great! Okay! Let's bolt. They start to go out. Harry stops by the door, points to answering machine.
Oh, there was a message. For you. I didn't feel like picking up. Peter goes to the machine, presses play.
Hello. This is Mary Jane Watson, star of the Broadway stage. (beat) You guys, I'm so nervous! Peter checks his watch.
Hmm. Geez, I hope the lecture's over by 7:30. I need to get down to the theater by 8.
Didn't you already see that lame show of hers?  10.
Twice.
Christ, Pete, I know you're her boyfriend, and all, but that's above and beyond.
Hey, tonight she's playing the lead! She's the, you know, the understudy. As they walk out of the apartment.
What, did she poison the leading lady?

Shut up. And I'm not her boyfriend. Bars descend, indicators flare, as they shut the door. INT. COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY — DAVIS AUDITORIUM — NIGHT Packed house of researchers, reporters, interested member the public. PROF. CZERNOWITZ is introducing Otto Octavius

.+.as a doctoral candidate he was dazzling. Now I'm afraid he's left us mere mortals far behind. It's my great honor to present, director of the Anansi Project, winner of a National Science Medal, Dr. Otto Octavius. APPLAUSE as Otto strides out. Younger than you might expe Wearing a long black Gaultier jacket. Smiling like a man with a surprise in store for us. He and Czernowitz meet. stiffness between them. Czernowitz looks intimidated.
Frank.
Otto. They shake hands awkwardly. Then Otto strides to the podi Grins, self mocking. Behind him on a table, a violin and bow. Piano to one side.  Laughter. 11.

He told you I was "dazzling," but what he's too nice to bring up is was what an insufferable little wretch I was. The lights dim; spot on Otto. Behind him a large flatpanel monitor descends. As he talks, the display will mirror, expand on and illustrate his words.

Biomimetics seeks to adapt for human use the technologies of other species. We poor humans have always envied our fellow creatures their talents; soon we will share them. Peter is rapt; Harry is playing Tetris on his Palm Pilot.

My own researches have been into arachnid technology: adapting, the remarkable abilities of spiders, their web-spinning abilities, their astonishing, almost precognitive impulse control. Harry notices how spellbound Peter is; leans over.
I will never understand this spider thing of yours. Peter takes no notice.

We had some success with manipulating spider RNA. But it's in the area of octopedal locomotion that things are really getting exciting. The goal is to provide stable motion on every possible kind of terrain and superior manipulation at a distance. Otto steps out from behind the podium.

You can't imagine the sheer number crunching might required to control and coordinate eight legs. Really tough. Actually, it was a chance visit to the Bronx Zoo that gave me the key insight.  12. He walks toward the monitor, which displays an octopus, a with a diagram of its nervous system.

The octopus has the equivalent of a powerful processor in each leg, networked to the central unit in her brain. The display fades to a diagram of the Rig, eight legs networked to each other through and to the center. The center is empty; then a diagrammatic human operator appea

Now, so far the capacity to control the full complement of eight legs is beyond our capacity. But we've been able to implement a similar system using... Otto takes a step forward, smiling a little coyly. Then f somewhere behind him a pair of glinting pseudopods snake The black stealth-bomber glint of superhard ceramic. A ga from the audience.
Four! Harry sits up. Puts away the Palm Pilot. The 'pods hover over Otto's shoulders a moment, undulant.
I call it a self-articulating network, but I'm afraid the name that has stuck is Otto's Octopus. One 'pod reaches to tap him on the shoulder.

Yes? Oh, thank you. It is a little warm in here. The arms help him out of the jacket, and as it comes off, another pair of pseudopods is revealed. The audience goes little nuts. One 'pod takes up the violin; another, the bow. The next snake out toward the piano; Otto strikes up a Grieg sonat With his own two hands, he takes out a fat cigar and ligh it; puffs contentedly. The audience, amazed, afraid, half suspecting that it's a prank.  13. Peter with a look of open-mouthed wonder. The music break off. Now the 'pods assume a configuration like a daddy long-le "toes" splayed against the dais, arching high into the ai Among them hangs, perfectly at ease, Otto. One at a time, turn, he raises and lowers each foot.
Each one of my four assistants here is equipped with its own hundred- teraflop processor. He begins to stride back and forth across the stage on hi four dancing pseudopods.
Computer architecture so sophisticated and capable of learning it approaches consciousness. He sinks back onto the two lower 'pods. The upper ones sn out around him.

At times I feel the Rig here has a life of its own. LEFT UPPER PSEUDOPOD takes a piece of paper from Otto's pocket. RIGHT UPPER produces a pen and scrawls something across the paper. Then the 'pod with the paper slaps it across Otto's back. He turns around, as if confused, walk on the lower pseudopods. The sign says GEEK! Laughter from the audience. They're eating this up. Otto, back to the audience, whirls his head around.

Given time, and a strong enough host... (rueful smile) ...its systems and my own would actually begin to integrate with each other-- The pseudopods rip away his shirt, revealing THE RIG nest right up against his spine, overlapping his own flesh.
--Merge into one organism.  14.
Shock, even revulsion at the sight of the implants. Then surge of APPLAUSE.
Gapes, bowled over.
You have to introduce me to him!
Don't you have a diva waiting? Peter checks his watch.
I can make it.

Otto lurches in on the pseudopods to a ROAR of applause f the hall. The 'pods telescope in and Otto falls to the floor. But o of the 'pods remains slightly extended. OTTO'S team crowds around him and drag him over to the NE COUPLER UNIT. They mount it around him. The TEAM LEADER twists the Rig's LATCH. This is a dial wi glass tube at its heart, like a spirit level, with a sing glowing bubble of air. He aligns the bubble with a mark a WHAM-the 'pod LASHES out and knocks the Team Leader aside
People are still applauding. But Peter's spider-sense TINGLES. He gets up.
I'll meet you in the lobby.
Where are you--
Too much coffee.

The Rig is out of control. Otto hangs from it like a doll The pseudopods whip and buzzsaw. Smash lightbulbs. Scatte humans.  15. Spider-Man leaps into the middle of the cyclone. He tries reach Otto. The 'pods feint and block. He fires web snares at the pods; pins them to the wall. T break free, lash out. Knock Spider-Man down. Spidey leaps up, fires a strand in either direction, snag the upper two ‘pods. Yanks them toward himself. Ties them a knot. They GRIND in protest. Keeping a grip on the knot he-- Spins a thick cocoon around each of the lower ones, paddi each out until it's a gently flailing balloon. The Rig struggles for a moment, then powers down. Otto falls to t floor, the ‘pods knotted across him. Spider-Man kneels beside Otto. Making sure he's okay. The Team Members hurry over with the coupler. Spider-Man out of the way. The team gets Otto into i and the Team Le twists the Latch. SPLORCH. The rig pops open. Otto falls out. We see that Otto's bare, muscular back is enhanced by fou neural sockets. They roll him over. Otto opens his eyes. The irises of his eyes seem to be leaking into the whites: pinwheels. Strange flowers. Octo
Look at his eyes!
We're overdoing the endorphin push.
That's the symbiosis routines in the Rig. It's actually trying to reconfigure his optical functions.
Was I... was I fighting Spider-Man? Everyone looks around at Spider-Man. Spider-Man's not the Otto sits up. They try to help him.
I'm fine! Thank you. I'm fine. Now, get off me. He stands up, shaky. Brushes off their helping hands.  16.
Otto, it was too long. You stayed in the Rig too long.

No, the problem is that I didn't stay in it long enough! My system never gets the chance to reach equilibrium with the Rig's! They stare at him. Is he serious? He looks around. Sees t broken light bulb. The slashed curtain. The shattered cha He sits down.
Maybe I stayed in the rig too long, I don't know. They bring him a glass of water and a clean shirt. He acc their ministrations.
Thank you. Thanks a lot, Teddy. (concerned) Are you all right? I didn't hurt you?
(relieved) I'm fine, chief.
Harry introduces Peter to Otto; they're shaking hands. Ot looks a bit frazzled but basically fine.
Doesn't it hurt to be jacked into that thing?
Actually, thanks to the endorphin boosters it feels very good. Coming out's a bitch.
It's so great to meet you. And the Rig's pretty--cool.
Still one or two-- (twitches his head) Kinks to work out. But basically sound.  17.
Actually, Doctor, I was hoping to hear you talk about the superspider research.

Ah. Well. Unfortunately we lost our funding for that project. I'm afraid it was rather poorly managed. And please... call me Otto. Any friend of the Osborns is my friend. The Rig's materials and kinetechnology is all Oscorp design and build. Norman Osborn was a huge supporter of my work. A steady and generous supporter. Not too mention a true original. A man, in a world of mediocrities. He's very sorely missed. At this mention of Norman, a shadow clouds Harry's face.
So I hear you're into spiders.
It's sort of a hobby.
And you guys had a--field trip? To our lab last year? I hope that was interesting?
Oh, yeah. Changed my life.
Pete? Not that I really care, but don't you have an ego extravaganza to get to? Peter looks at his watch: it's 7:45.
Jeez! Oh, my God. I have to go. Now!
Ego extravaganza?
It's our friend--  18.
Your friend.
--MJ. Mary Jane Watson. She's in this musical. She's the understudy and she's making her big debut in fifteen minutes. He shakes hands with Otto, then starts away.

You ought to check it out, I bet you'd really get into it. EXT. MARTIN BECK THEATER — NIGHT The Marquee reads: BRIDE! Over it, enormous cutouts of Dr Frankenstein and the Bride. The name Deirdre DUNN plaster everywhere. A tour bus pulls up in front of the theater. The nameplat reads: MT. NEBO CENTER FOR ASSISTED LIVING. A BUNCH OF OL LADIES file out. We're with two of the ladies, SOPHIE and ROSE. As they en the lobby, they are each handed a program. Rose notices a leaf of paper poking from the program. Tug out.
What's this?

head_text.subj: DURING TONIGHT'S PERFORMANCE, THE ROLE OF ELIZABETH
FRANKENSTEIN WILL BE PLAYED BY MARY JANE WATSON.

text: Wouldn't you know it. Sixty dollars a ticket and we get the understudy.
Deirdre's probably in rehab again.

Frenetic stagehands make last minute changes. Actors loit in the wings. We travel down the wings, past actors and c who crowd the stairs, down to the dressing rooms. MJ WATSON sits at the mirror, making little adjustments t her makeup.  19. She's in costume as Elizabeth Frankenstein and holding a blond wig in her hands. RENARD, the actor playing HENRY FRANKENSTEIN, lounges beside her, calm where she's worried. He's very good-looking.
Just remember, acting is reacting. Mo Got it. Clearly troubled rather than nervous. The door to the dressing room opens. MJ turns expectantly. ANOTHER ACTOR' there, costumed as an Angry Villager.
Did you check Will Call?
The ticket is still there. MJ looks sad. Puts on the wig, tugs it straight, and smil at herself. Big theatrical smile. The show must go on. Renard pulls a chair over, sits down right beside MJ.
Hey, cheer up. There's a TV crew here, you know. From New York 1. They heard about your big debut.
How did they hear?
I don't know. Somebody must have called them. Somebody who likes the way you... act. Flirting hard. He brushes a flake of mascara from her che
So, who is he, your Mr. No-Show?
A friend of mine.
Boyfriend?
No. Just a friend. I thought he might want to see my debut, but I guess he doesn't.  20.
Eh, who needs him?
(resolute) That's what I say. Who needs him? The STAGE MANAGER comes in.
MJ? You ready? I/E. THEATER — NIGHT Peter tears into the lobby. Runs up to the theater door. burly USHER stops him.
Whoa. You can't go in there. Nobody seated once the performance begins. Points to a sign which confirms this.
But I--
It's to help maintain the illusion.
I understand. But I have to get in there. Mary Jane Watson is a friend of mine.
And as far as I can tell, she is a very nice young lady. (beat) Nobody seated once the performance begins. You can go in at intermission.
When's that?
(checks watch) About forty-two minutes from now.

Nice picture. A little sultry.  21. INT. THEATER — LOBBY - NIGHT It's on a wall by the front doors. Peter's gazing at the picture. Just kind of amazed by how pretty she looks. Spider-sense TINGLES. SIREN in the distance. Faint SQUEAL of tires. INT. THEATER — ONSTAGE - NIGHT MJ as Elizabeth with Renard as Henry F. Henry is singing big number, "I Created A Man." MJ emotes back at him. Her gaze strays toward the house. Right in the front row, a glaringly empty seat. Back on MJ. She sings.
Way at the at the back of the house.

She's terrible. INT. THEATER — NIGHT SIREN is louder. Peter ducks out into the street. Somethi is happening and he needs to stop it. It's coming from ov on Broadway. A CAR flashes through the intersection of 45th and Ninth. Driving way too fast. In traffic. Skids. Smashes into a c Then another. Then keeps on going downtown. Two seconds later, one two three police cruisers. Peter looks back at the theater. Then at his watch. Then to the avenue.
It's not your problem, Pete. It's the police's problem. It's not your problem.

The car roars down the avenue, weaving in and out. The cruisers in pursuit. It's a rag-top; THREE GUYS. Two in the back with machine guns. Oh, like Spider-Man didn't see that coming! Spider flies elegantly through their fire. Snags the two shooter Pins them to light posts and hangs them out for the polic  22. Now Spider-Man turns to the DRIVER. Lands on the car. Is thrown off. Shot at. Keeps coming back. In the end he crawls under the car, comes over top, webs the Driver's gun. Manages to get them both out just befor the car slams into a big construction site dumpster and EXPLODES.
TWO POLICEMEN come running over. Spider-Man lowers the po bastard down to them on a line, headfirst. They grab him cuff him. One leads him away. The other looks up at Spide Man.
There's no way I can not arrest you for that.
Duly noted. He fires a web and swings back uptown.
It's a lot safer in jail, Spider- Man!

Spider-Man, swings back toward the theater. Spider sense TINGLES. His head snaps left. Atop a building nearby, the flash of a sniper's rifle. Th next instant a shot rings out. A bullet snips the draglin neatly in two. It goes slack and Spider-Man falls out of sky. Spider-Man plummets to the ground. A MOTHER is pushing TWINS in a stroller. Right under him. Moving like a diver he twists around. Fires a web that sn a small billboard across the street. He stops falling. The webbing peels the entire top sheet off the billboard, a single piece. Peter falls the last four feet or so. Man to arrest his fall, slamming his shoulder into the paveme Nearly hits the TWINS.

Maniac! Idiot! Peter stumbles to his feet. Two big BRUISERS rush him. On carries a pair of heavy-duty handcuffs. They're on him. They're big, but Peter handles them easily with a little kung fu. Then he looks up.  23. Scans the skies over Ninth Avenue. All quiet. There's not there now.
Hey, look. It's the ten million dollar man. Spider-Man looks down. And sees that a crowd has gathered around him. Most just staring at him like hungry dogs.

We get five, six guys together, we could take him. That's like, what, two million apiece. Come on. But he doesn't step forward. Nobody steps forward. Then a little kid steps forward. Twelve or thirteen.
You in for it now. The kid hands Spider-Man an early copy of tomorrow's Bugl THE PHOTO PETER SOLD HIM TODAY(captioned SPIDER MAN ASSAU NUN!!!) and THE HEADLINE: WANTED -- $10,000,000 REWARD.
Ten million dollars. I should arrest myself. Bounds right over them and then into the night.
Give it your best shot, New York. INT. MARTIN BECK THEATER — LOBBY - NIGHT Peter comes tearing back in. The lobby's ominously empty. same usher stands there. Ready for Peter.
Tell me I didn't miss intermission. In reply the usher just crosses his arms.
MJ is having a deep scene with the Monster and the Bride, just before the tragic conclusion.  24. At the back of the theater, one of the old ladies watches expressionless. Her friend is sound asleep.
Peter waits, watching the door. Some actors come out. Pet perks up--no. Then she's there.
She sees him, is pierced through by the sight of him--and keeps walking. He goes after her.
MJ. Please. She keeps going. He takes her by the arm. She shakes it o She isn't going to even speak to him. On second thought-- turns back to him.
You know, when you said you wanted to be friends, I believed you.
I do want to be friends.
Well, then you aren't a very good friend, are you?
I tried, MJ. I got here. I mean, I was a little late. They wouldn't let me in.
But you missed everything! All of it! Why didn't you come in at intermission? Peter doesn't know how to answer this; can't lie fast eno
Well--there was an accident--in the street. I went to get a picture and-- She doesn't want to hear it. Starts away again.  She looks 25.
MJ. I do want to be your friend. I'm sorry. Please. at him. Is she softening? Peter will never know. Renard comes out of the theater. Checks out Peter. Gives her Pete. Her Peter the
Good night, MJ. You were wonderful. a big hug. When he lets go, MJ is staring right at look says, See? You could lose me. Renard gives fisheye and then walks off.
MJ. You aren't-- are you...
Renard's just a friend. Why. Do you wish I was seeing somebody? Would you like to get rid of me and for all?

No. No, I think you enjoy this idea you have that I'm going around carrying a torch for you. Which I'm not. (beat) No, I'm not seeing anybody, Peter. But you know what? I might meet someone. I might even fall in love with somebody. Tomorrow. And then nobody will be carrying a torch for you. And then what will you do? She's angry. He looks like he thinks she has a right to b
MJ. You don't know. You don't know how much I think about you. How much I--

No, that's right. I don't know anything. I've known you since the first grade but I don't know anything about you.  26. Peter takes a step toward her. Looks into her eyes. Six inches of air separates him from having her. His PAGER goes off. He's embarrassed, fumbles with it.
Sorry. It's--oh. It's Aunt May. She hardly ever pages me. I better-- MJ watches him go. Typical.
Peter's on the phone, worried.
Aunt May? Aunt May, what's the matter? Why are you crying?
Aunt May's in her bathrobe, sitting at the kitchen table. so quietly losing it.
What's the matter? I'm going out of my mind, that's what the matter! I can't take it any more!
Peter is distressed.
Okay, okay, Aunt May, settle down. I'm coming. He hangs up, and runs back down to the alley where he lef MJ. But she's gone.
Peter races out to Queens on his lousy motorcycle.

Peter comes running into the house at top speed, tears in the kitchen. Aunt May's just sitting there, not crying. Scarily still, holding a cup of tea, in a pool of light. Nice plate of cookies beside her.  27.
Aunt May? What--
There's a fly.
A fly?
A fly, a bee, I don't know what it is. Buzzing all around the house, it's driving me insane! Who can sleep with a racket like that? PETER: Okay.
All right. I'll take care of it.
I tried to kill it myself, but I can't. I don't know where it is. Peter cocks an ear, his hearing spider-sharp.
It's in the bedroom on your lamp. She gives him a look; how did he know that?

Peter steps into the bedroom and closes the door behind h His eyes dart to a porcelain shepherdess holding up a for watt bulb and a gilt-edged shade. There on the shepherdess's bonnet perches a big fat juicy fly. If we could detect such things, we would sense that fly feels a sudden alarm.
Aunt May hears the THWING of Spidey's webbing and then a SPLAT. Peter emerges from the bedroom, looking satisfied.
Mission accomplished.  A beat. 28.
I'm sorry, Peter. I know you must think I'm losing my mind. It's just-- your uncle always killed the bugs around here.
He was a handy guy to have around. (beat) I never realized how much I depended on his advice.
Something on your mind?
Well--
You could talk to me, you know.
Yeah, I know that. But I--
Peter... (taking a chance) I've seen the change that has come over you since Ben died. Everyone has. Peter looks startled. Guilty.
Change...? I don't... What do you mean?
